A **ki-rin**, A, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Ki-rin are quadrupedal, [animalistic](/wiki/Animal "Animal") [angelic beings](/wiki/Angelic_being "Angelic being") that are [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong"), capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight"), possess [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), can be seen via infravision, and can [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible"). They are the second-strongest angelic beings after [Archons](/wiki/Archon "Archon").

A ki-rin has two kick attacks, a headbutt attack, and will attempt to cast one mage [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") during each of its turns.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Ki-rin have [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and are no longer considered [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal"). They also have the ability to cure themselves using their horns, like [unicorn horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") - as they do not leave corpses, their horns will not drop.

## Generation

Randomly generated ki-rin may generate as [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") for a [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") character with a good [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"). They are not eligible forms for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph"), and will not randomly generate in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom").

A hostile ki-rin can be generated as the [minion](/wiki/Minion "Minion") of a lawful [god](/wiki/God "God").

Ki-rin cannot be targeted for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

## Strategy

Hostile ki-rin are quite dangerous to face: a repertoire of mage [monster spells](/wiki/Monster_spells "Monster spells"), 18 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), an [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of -5, and a high [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 90 can all make the ki-rin a serious nuisance at best, especially if they generate at a high enough [level](/wiki/Monster_level "Monster level") to [summon nasties](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") or even employ the [touch of death](/wiki/Touch_of_death "Touch of death"). Furthermore, as angelic beings they do not respect sanctuary or [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth"). Fortunately, they are randomly generated very rarely, and will only ever be seen around the Castle or on the [ascension run](/wiki/Ascension_run "Ascension run").

Well-prepared characters fighting a hostile ki-rin can take advantage of their lack of actual resistances and weaken or even kill them from a distance before they can get into casting range, though this will still prove difficult with their base speed and ability to cast [haste self](/wiki/Haste_self_\(monster_spell\) "Haste self (monster spell)"). A character's best options include high-enchantment [missile](/wiki/Missile "Missile") weapons or a high-damage attack spell such as [magic missile](/wiki/Spellbook_of_magic_missile "Spellbook of magic missile"). [Magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), good AC and a well-enchanted weapon (typically an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") at the stage you encounter them) are highly recommended when facing a ki-rin. Though ki-rin are very difficult to [scare](/wiki/Scare "Scare"), as animals an [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") [mirror](/wiki/Mirror "Mirror") can scare them 4⁄5 of the time.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Ki-rin are no longer animals, making scaring them even more difficult.

### As pets

Ki-rin are highly sought-after [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") for their flight, base 18 speed, fighting power, and -5 AC, to the point that some players will use a [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for a blessed [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of one. Their MR of 90 makes them very difficult to tame normally, but also ensures they will never buck you off a saddle due to [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict") unless they are [level drained](/wiki/Level_drain "Level drain") below 15; fast ki-rin also have the same speed as an unhasted [warhorse](/wiki/Warhorse "Warhorse") or [unicorn](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn").

Ki-rin also also among the best choice of [steed](/wiki/Steed "Steed") for [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") and other roles capable of advancing the riding skill - they are also among the most likely to survive a trip through [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). However, even a ki-rin will have trouble surviving the [Elemental Planes](/wiki/Elemental_Planes "Elemental Planes"), and their lack of resistances often spells doom if they are caught in [poison clouds](/wiki/Poison_cloud "Poison cloud") on the [Plane of Fire](/wiki/Plane_of_Fire "Plane of Fire"). Furthermore, they are inediate and cannot have their tameness raised with food – a tame ki-rin ridden by any non-Knight will inevitably be untamed after being mounted, kicked, or whipped five times. Knights are the only role that can reliably keep a tame ki-rin for long amounts of time due to their special role quality - non-Knights should not dismount their ki-rin steed unless absolutely necessary, and should ideally have Basic riding skill before obtaining one.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Pets that eat corpses can also gain intrinsics from them, making the inediate ki-rin a slightly weaker choice for a pet in the long term; fortunately, a ki-rin's survival chances are buffed due to their poison resistance, and the horn can aid them in surviving the Plane of Fire's [gas plumes](/wiki/Poison_cloud "Poison cloud").

Conflict has also undergone several changes - among other things, it works based on the player's [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") and the levels of them and the affected monsters, making it possible that a character with conflict can be bucked off their ki-rin.

## History

The ki-rin, u, first appears in [NetHack-- 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack--_3.0.10 "NetHack-- 3.0.10"), where it is part of the [quadruped](/wiki/Quadruped "Quadruped") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"). The ki-rin is introduced to vanilla *NetHack* alongside the other angelic beings in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"), and its glyph is changed to A; it retains this glyph for its appearance in [NetHack-- 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack--_3.1.3 "NetHack-- 3.1.3").

From [NetHack 3.4.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.1 "NetHack 3.4.1") to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including many variants based on these versions, ki-rin are able to wear amulets, boots, shields, and gloves despite being non-humanoid - this is [bug C341-18](/wiki/Bug#C341-18 "Bug"), and is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"). Outfitting a ki-rin with an [amulet](/wiki/Amulet_of_reflection "Amulet of reflection") or [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection") is a popular choice for pet-keeping players in these versions, both to augment their already-formidable AC and protect against rays from a [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Qilin](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qilin "wikipedia:Qilin")***

The *qilin* or *kirin* is a chimerical quadruped creature that appears in Chinese folklore, and is said to appear with the imminent arrival or passing of a sage or illustrious ruler. The earliest references to the qilin occur in the 5th century BCE - its legendary image became associated with the image of the giraffe in the Ming dynasty after Zheng He's 15th-century voyage to East Africa. Qilin are described as quiet-hooved herbivores with a reputed ability to "walk on grass without disturbing it", which may be related to the giraffe's long, thin legs. The qilin is also described as having antlers like a deer and scales like a dragon or fish.

In modern times, "qilin" is sometimes translated into English as "[unicorn](/wiki/Unicorn "Unicorn")" due to the qilin sometimes having a single horn. This can be misleading, as a number of different Chinese mythical creatures can be depicted with a single horn, and such a qilin would be called a "one-horned qilin" in Chinese. With this in mind, the qilin and unicorn are often given similar traits in contemporary and modern portrayals.

## Variants

Variants based on 3.4.3 that intentionally leave bug C341-18 intact may allow a ki-rin to wear additional equipment.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), tame ki-rin can be given as [sacrifice gifts](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") or [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer") boons to lawful players from [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 13 to 19, though minions cannot be saddled or ridden. Ki-rin require a +3 weapon to hit, while their attacks hit as +3 weapons. This makes them even better as pets and steeds, rendering them immune to physical attacks from powerful [minotaurs](/wiki/Minotaur "Minotaur") and even some [demon princes](/wiki/Demon_prince "Demon prince") - but it also makes them far more dangerous should you encounter a hostile one.

SLASH'EM incorporates bug C341-18 as a feature, allowing ki-rin to wear amulets and non-body armor. Ki-rin can obtain reflection from an amulet or shield of reflection - they are not level-drain or stoning resistant, however, so an [amulet of drain resistance](/wiki/Amulet_of_drain_resistance "Amulet of drain resistance") or an [amulet versus stone](/wiki/Amulet_versus_stone "Amulet versus stone") is also a good option for their amulet slot.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") introduces the [eldritch ki-rin](/wiki/Eldritch_ki-rin "Eldritch ki-rin"), a "fallen angel" ki-rin that serves as a chaotic counterpart: they can appear in Gehennom and can only be tamed by chaotic Knights, for whom they are an excellent steed choice.

## Encyclopedia entry

The ki-rin is a strange-looking flying creature. It has  
scales, a mane like a lion, a tail, hooves, and a horn. It  
is brightly colored, and can usually be found flying in the  
sky looking for good deeds to reward.

They are the second-strongest angelic beings after [[Archon]]s.

A ki-rin has two kick attacks, a headbutt attack, and will attempt to cast one mage [[monster spell]] during each of its turns.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Ki-rin have [[poison resistance]], and are no longer considered [[animal]]s. They also have the ability to cure themselves using their horns, like [[unicorn horn]]s - as they do not leave corpses, their horns will not drop.}}

==Generation==
Randomly generated ki-rin may generate as [[peaceful]] for a [[lawful]] character with a good [[alignment record]]. They are not eligible forms for [[polymorph]], and will not randomly generate in [[Gehennom]].

A hostile ki-rin can be generated as the [[minion]] of a lawful [[god]].

Ki-rin cannot be targeted for [[genocide]].

==Strategy==
Hostile ki-rin are quite dangerous to face: a repertoire of mage [[monster spells]], 18 [[speed]], an [[AC]] of -5, and a high [[magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 90 can all make the ki-rin a serious nuisance at best, especially if they generate at a high enough [[Monster level|level]] to [[summon nasties]] or even employ the [[touch of death]]. Furthermore, as angelic beings they do not respect sanctuary or [[Elbereth]]. Fortunately, they are randomly generated very rarely, and will only ever be seen around the Castle or on the [[ascension run]].

Well-prepared characters fighting a hostile ki-rin can take advantage of their lack of actual resistances and weaken or even kill them from a distance before they can get into casting range, though this will still prove difficult with their base speed and ability to cast [[Haste self (monster spell)|haste self]]. A character's best options include high-enchantment [[missile]] weapons or a high-damage attack spell such as {{spell of|magic missile}}. [[Magic resistance]], good AC and a well-enchanted weapon (typically an [[artifact weapon]] at the stage you encounter them) are highly recommended when facing a ki-rin. Though ki-rin are very difficult to [[scare]], as animals an [[applied]] [[mirror]] can scare them {{frac|4|5}} of the time.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Ki-rin are no longer animals, making scaring them even more difficult.}}

===As pets===
Ki-rin are highly sought-after [[pet]]s for their flight, base 18 speed, fighting power, and -5 AC, to the point that some players will use a [[wish]] for a blessed [[figurine]] of one. Their MR of 90 makes them very difficult to tame normally, but also ensures they will never buck you off a saddle due to [[conflict]] unless they are [[level drain]]ed below 15; fast ki-rin also have the same speed as an unhasted [[warhorse]] or [[unicorn]].

Ki-rin also also among the best choice of [[steed]] for [[Knight]]s and other roles capable of advancing the riding skill - they are also among the most likely to survive a trip through [[Gehennom]]. However, even a ki-rin will have trouble surviving the [[Elemental Planes]], and their lack of resistances often spells doom if they are caught in [[poison cloud]]s on the [[Plane of Fire]]. Furthermore, they are inediate and cannot have their tameness raised with food – a tame ki-rin ridden by any non-Knight will inevitably be untamed after being mounted, kicked, or whipped five times. Knights are the only role that can reliably keep a tame ki-rin for long amounts of time due to their special role quality - non-Knights should not dismount their ki-rin steed unless absolutely necessary, and should ideally have Basic riding skill before obtaining one.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Pets that eat corpses can also gain intrinsics from them, making the inediate ki-rin a slightly weaker choice for a pet in the long term; fortunately, a ki-rin's survival chances are buffed due to their poison resistance, and the horn can aid them in surviving the Plane of Fire's [[poison cloud|gas plumes]].

Conflict has also undergone several changes - among other things, it works based on the player's [[charisma]] and the levels of them and the affected monsters, making it possible that a character with conflict can be bucked off their ki-rin.}}

==History==
The ki-rin, {{yellow|u}}, first appears in [[NetHack-- 3.0.10]], where it is part of the [[quadruped]] [[monster class]]. The ki-rin is introduced to vanilla ''NetHack'' alongside the other angelic beings in [[NetHack 3.1.0]], and its glyph is changed to {{yellow|A}}; it retains this glyph for its appearance in [[NetHack-- 3.1.3]].

From [[NetHack 3.4.1]] to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including many variants based on these versions, ki-rin are able to wear amulets, boots, shields, and gloves despite being non-humanoid - this is [[Bug#C341-18|bug C341-18]], and is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]]. Outfitting a ki-rin with an [[amulet of reflection|amulet]] or [[shield of reflection]] is a popular choice for pet-keeping players in these versions, both to augment their already-formidable AC and protect against rays from a [[wand of death]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Qilin}}
The ''qilin'' or ''kirin'' is a chimerical quadruped creature that appears in Chinese folklore, and is said to appear with the imminent arrival or passing of a sage or illustrious ruler. The earliest references to the qilin occur in the 5th century BCE - its legendary image became associated with the image of the giraffe in the Ming dynasty after Zheng He's 15th-century voyage to East Africa. Qilin are described as quiet-hooved herbivores with a reputed ability to "walk on grass without disturbing it", which may be related to the giraffe's long, thin legs. The qilin is also described as having antlers like a deer and scales like a dragon or fish.

In modern times, "qilin" is sometimes translated into English as "[[unicorn]]" due to the qilin sometimes having a single horn. This can be misleading, as a number of different Chinese mythical creatures can be depicted with a single horn, and such a qilin would be called a "one-horned qilin" in Chinese. With this in mind, the qilin and unicorn are often given similar traits in contemporary and modern portrayals.<!--This includes the ability to cure themselves with their horn in 3.7.0.-->

==Variants==
Variants based on 3.4.3 that intentionally leave bug C341-18 intact may allow a ki-rin to wear additional equipment. 

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], tame ki-rin can be given as [[sacrifice gift]]s or [[prayer]] boons to lawful players from [[experience level]]s 13 to 19, though minions cannot be saddled or ridden. Ki-rin require a +3 weapon to hit, while their attacks hit as +3 weapons. This makes them even better as pets and steeds, rendering them immune to physical attacks from powerful [[minotaur]]s and even some [[demon prince]]s - but it also makes them far more dangerous should you encounter a hostile one.

SLASH'EM incorporates bug C341-18 as a feature, allowing ki-rin to wear amulets and non-body armor. Ki-rin can obtain reflection from an amulet or shield of reflection - they are not level-drain or stoning resistant, however, so an [[amulet of drain resistance]] or an [[amulet versus stone]] is also a good option for their amulet slot.

===EvilHack===
[[EvilHack]] introduces the [[eldritch ki-rin]], a "fallen angel" ki-rin that serves as a chaotic counterpart: they can appear in Gehennom and can only be tamed by chaotic Knights, for whom they are an excellent steed choice.
